multiQuestions.question: Which storage option shares access for multiple users and is comparable to NAS storage (on prem)?
What storage option has items stored by a flat address space and referenced by a unique key
What is the largest size an individual S3 file can be?
Which Storage Tier is good for when the access to the object will be unkown?
Which Storage Tier always puts and keeps objects in the Infrequent Access Tier?
Which Storage Tier has infrequent access and only duplicates objects across one AZ rather than across multiple AZs like the other Storage Tiers?
How long does it take for S3 INT Tier to move Frequent Access Tier to the Infrequent Access Tier?
What are the 3 retrieval options of S3 Glacier, from cheapest to most expensive?
How long can it take to retrieve an item from S3 Glacier using the Expedited retreival option
What does S3 INT stand for?
What does S3 S-IA stand for?
What does S3 Z-IA stand for?
What does S3 G-DA stand for?
For S3 Glacier, buckets are called ___ and objects are called ___
What do Lifecycle Rules do?
multiQuestions.answer: Provide an automatic method of managing the life of your data while it is being stored on S3. Such as moving to another S3 bucket, or deleting the object entirely after a period of time. (For cost saving)

multiQuestions.question: What is Server-Access Logging?
multiQuestions.answer: When enabled, captures and logs requests made to the bucket & its objects and sends them to a Target Bucket as a Log Delivery Group

multiQuestions.question: What is Object-Level Logging?
multiQuestions.answer: When enabled, uses API CloudTrail to track API requests made to objects (PutObject, DeleteObject, etc). Stores it into a Log File which is then stored in S3

multiQuestions.question: What is Transfer Acceleration?
multiQuestions.answer: Using CloudFront to create a CDN (Content Delivery Network) to enable requests to go through Edge Locations to quickly access S3 (and other services). There is a cost per gigabyte of this featuer whereas regular S3 requests are free

multiQuestions.question: What does CORS (Cross Origin Resource Sharing) do?
multiQuestions.answer: Allows resources on a web page to be requested from a different domain than its own

multiQuestions.question: How do you enable CORS for an S3 Bucket?
multiQuestions.answer: Enable it in the Bucket Policy JSON under the AllowedHeaders property ("*")

multiQuestions.question: Which storage service is best used for uploading a file once, and then reading it many many times?
Which storage service stores and updates data as chunks, and is great for low latency, fast, and persistent storage?
How many storage classes does EFS have?
For EFS, you can move files automatically between Standard and Infrequent Access storage classes by using
What does the General Purpose performance mode for EFS do?
multiQuestions.answer: Provides you with throughput to your files of up to 35,000 operations per second, with lower latency and being cheaper than with Max I/O
wrongAnswers: Allows you to provision for the expected throughput, no matter the file system's size, but is more expensive
Provisions throughput for read/write operations based off of your file system's size. Allows you to 'burst' above your baseline with Burst Credits, but you will be throttled when out of credits
Gives you virtually unlimited throughput to your files, but with higher latency, and is more expensive

multiQuestions.question: What does Max I/O performance mode for EFS do?
multiQuestions.answer: Gives you virtually unlimited throughput to your files, but with higher latency, and is more expensive
wrongAnswers: Allows you to provision for the expected throughput, no matter the file system's size, but is more expensive
Provisions throughput for read/write operations based off of your file system's size. Allows you to 'burst' above your baseline with Burst Credits, but you will be throttled when out of credits
Provides you with throughput to your files of up to 35,000 operations per second, with lower latency and being cheaper than with Max I/O

multiQuestions.question: What does Bursting Throughput for EFS do?
multiQuestions.answer: Provisions throughput for read/write operations based off of your file system's size. Allows you to 'burst' above your baseline with Burst Credits, but you will be throttled when out of credits
wrongAnswers: Allows you to provision for the expected throughput, no matter the file system's size, but is more expensive
Gives you virtually unlimited throughput to your files, but with higher latency, and is more expensive
Provides you with throughput to your files of up to 35,000 operations per second, with lower latency and being cheaper than with Max I/O

multiQuestions.question: What does Provisioned Throughput for EFS do?
multiQuestions.answer: Allows you to provision for the expected throughput, no matter the file system's size, but is more expensive
wrongAnswers: Provisions throughput for read/write operations based off of your file system's size. Allows you to 'burst' above your baseline with Burst Credits, but you will be throttled when out of credits
Gives you virtually unlimited throughput to your files, but with higher latency, and is more expensive
Provides you with throughput to your files of up to 35,000 operations per second, with lower latency and being cheaper than with Max I/O

multiQuestions.question: Which is the best Throughput Mode if you have a small data size but need a very large amount of reads/writes
What are Burst Credits
multiQuestions.answer: Credits that are a part of Burst Throughput mode that accrue automatically and decrease as you go above the expected base throughput. Once you run out, throughput will be throttled

multiQuestions.question: What is Encryption in Transit?
multiQuestions.answer: A way to encrypt data from EFS all the way to the end client, using TLS (Transport Layer Security)

multiQuestions.question: How do you enable Encryption in Transit?
multiQuestions.answer: When SSHd into the EC2 instance to connect it to the Mount Point, enter a terminal command to set TLS up using Stunnel

multiQuestions.answer: Just enable it for the volume in the AWS Console

Which EBS Volume Type lets you set the IOPS rate you expect and gives consistent results
Which EBS Volume Type is good for frequently accessed data and large data sets and cannot be used as boot volumes for your instances
Which EBS Volume Type has the  lowest cost and is good for infrequent access and large amounts of data
What service provides a fully managed Windows file system on AWS
multiQuestions.answer: Amazon FSx for Windows File Server

multiQuestions.question: What is a feature of FSx for Windows File Server that can save you from 30% or 80% on storage costs
Data deduplication is a feature of ___

multiQuestions.question: Which AWS service offers a centrilized location for backups of all storage services in all regions?
How do you create a backup with AWS Backup?
multiQuestions.answer: Create a backup policy (also known as a backup plan), and then attach a resource to the plan

multiQuestions.question: What are some way to benefit from cheaper storage when using AWS Backup?
multiQuestions.answer: By using cold storage, and lifecycle rules to delete objects after a period of time

multiQuestions.question: A company needs to maintain access logs for a minimum of five years due to regulatory requirements. The data is rarely accessed once stored but it must be accessible within one day's notice if it is needed. What is the most cost-effective data storage solution that meets these requirements?
multiQuestions.answer: Store the data in Amazon S3 Glacier Deep Archive storage and delete the objects after 5 years using a lifecycle rule
wrongAnswers: Store the data in Amazon S3 Standard storage and transition to Amazon S3 Glacier after 30 days using a lifecycle rule
Store the data in logs using Amazon CloudWatch Logs and set the retentino period to 5 years
Store the data in Amazon S3 Standard-Infrequent Access (S3 Standard-IA) storage and delete the objects after 5 years using a lifecycle rule

multiQuestions.question: When storing data in Amaon S3, you can define ___ to automatically archive sets of Amazon S3 objects to less expensive Amazon S3 storage classes
A user has hosted objects on AWS in the bucket cloudacademy. Can a JavaScript of the website www.myvideos.com directly access the objects of the bucket?
wrongAnswers: No, one domain cannot interact with the objects of another domain

multiQuestions.question: An IT department manages a content management system (CMS) running on an Amazon EC2 instance mounted to an Elastic File System (EFS). The CMS throughput demands are high compared to the amount of data stored on the file system. What is the appropriate EFS configuration in this case?
multiQuestions.answer: Choose Provisioned Throughput mode for the file system
wrongAnswers: Choose Bursting Throughput mode for the file system
Start with the General Purpose performance mode and update the file system to Max I/O if it reaches its I/O limit
Start with Bursting Throughput mode and update the file system to Max I/O if it reaches its I/O limit

multiQuestions.question: A photo-sharing application uses a fleet of EC2 instances to assemble photos into a package that professional photographers can share with clients. To improve performance, the team uses multiple Amazon EC2 instances in parallel to resize and prepare each image with a watermark. Now, during the build process, the EC2 instances requires shared access to common storage to retrieve and save each photograph in the package. After the package is complete, it should be stored in the cloud so that only authorized clients can review the contents. Which of the following storage solutions will allow shared access between EC2 instances and enable clients access to the final package described in this scenario?
multiQuestions.answer: (1) Use Elastic File Storage (Amazon EFS) for persistent storage shared across EC2 instances. (2) Save client packages to a private Amazon S3 bucket and provide client access using a CloudFront signed URL
wrongAnswers: (1) Use Elastic Block Storage (Amazon EBS) for persistent storage shared across EC2 instances. (2) Save packages to a private Amazon S3 bucket, create an IAM user for the client, and grant this user read access to the S3 bucket

(1) Use Elastic Block Storage (Amazon EBS) for persistent storage shared cross EC2 instances. (2) Save client packages to a private Amazon S3 bucket and provide client access using a CloudFront signed URL

(1) Use Elastic File Storage (Amazon EFS) for persistent storage shared across EC2 instances. (2) Save packages to a private Amazon S3 bucket, create an IAM user for the client, and grant this user read access to the S3 bucket

multiQuestions.question: You have an unencrypted EBS volume that now needs to be encrypted in another region. How do you do this?
multiQuestions.answer: One way would be to take a snapshot of the volume, copy the snapshot to the correct region, create a new volume from that snapshot and then select 'encrypt' when creating the volume

multiQuestions.question: A research institution has a growing number of source code repositories hosted on multiple servers and managed by different IT departments. The institution plans to consolidate these repositories and deploy GitHub Enterprise Server on a single Amazon EC2 instance. The team needs to select the most appropriate Amazon storage service for the data volume of the instance running the GitHub server enterprise. Which of the following storage solutions would the team choose for this deployment?

A company maintains an on-premise data center and performs daily data backups to disk and tape storage to comply with regulatory requirements. The IT department is looking for an AWS cloud solution to backup its data. The IT department responsible for this project plans to continue maintaining the primary data onsite and is looking for an AWS cloud solution for data backup that will work well with their current archiving process. What should the following AWS storage services should the team choose to manage its data backup requirements?
What is Requester Pay?
multiQuestions.answer: A setting in S3 that when enabled, the entity downloading data from that bucket will pay data transfer costs incurred

multiQuestions.question: To migrate data from on-prem to AWS EFS, with plans to stop using on-prem data afterwards, you should use
To migrate data from on-prem to AWS S3, with plans to use both in a hybrid way, you should use

booleanQuestions.question: S3 has an object hierarchy
booleanQuestions.popup: You can create folders for organization, but objects are retrieved by a unique key and do not depend on folders or hierarchies

booleanQuestions.question: S3 is highly available, durable, cost effective, widely accessible
For S3 to be duplicated to multiple AZs, you need to enable it
booleanQuestions.popup: It is enabled by default with different durability and availability depending on your Storage Class (except for S3 Z-IA which is only one zone)

booleanQuestions.question: S3 buckets can have any name
booleanQuestions.popup: S3 buckets must have globally unique names

booleanQuestions.question: S3 Versioning is disabled by default
Once S3 Versioning is enabled, it can't be disabled, only suspended
booleanQuestions.popup: It can only be suspended. All previous versions will still exist

booleanQuestions.question: Server-Access Logging is garaunteed to work for every request to your S3 bucket
booleanQuestions.popup: Not garaunteed, is on a best effort basis

booleanQuestions.question: If 'block all public access' is checked in an S3 bucket, but ACL says to allow public access, public access is allowed through
booleanQuestions.popup: 'block all public access' overrides ACL (and I assume Bucket Policies and IAM)

booleanQuestions.question: For EFS, the Infrequent Access storage class is cheaper than the Standard storage class
booleanQuestions.popup: Infrequent Access is cheaper than Standard, but unlike Standard, it does charge you per every read & write

booleanQuestions.question: KMS Customer Managed Keys (CMKs) can only be used by the service they were created for
EC2 instances need IAM policies to speak to EFS and its Mount Points

AWS DataSync lets you migrate data from an on-prem NFS file system to AWS EFS, migrate an NFS file system from an EC2 instance to EFS, and replicate data from EFS to another EFS in another region, even adding Lifecycle Managment to the files
AWS DataSync will keep your on-prem files and your EFS files syncronized while migrating to EFS
EC2 Instance Storage is great for critical or valuable data that you don't want to lose
Instance Storage is often used within a load balancing group, where data is replicated and pooled between the fleet of instances
EBS is great if you need high durability and availability of your data
booleanQuestions.popup: You should use S3 or EFS instead - EBS Volumes are only stored in one AZ

booleanQuestions.question: EBS volumes sit on the same host as the server that hosts the EC2 instance
booleanQuestions.popup: EBS volumes are logically attached to the EC2 instance (over the AWS network) instead of directly connected at the hardward level like Instance Storage is

booleanQuestions.question: There is a setting for EBS volumes to self-terminate or attach to another EC2 instance, when its connected EC2 instance terminates
When creating snapshots of an EBS volume, all data is stored in the snapshot
booleanQuestions.popup: EBS Snapshots are Incremental. Meaning only data that has changed since the last snapshot is stored in the new snapshot

booleanQuestions.question: You can create a new EBS volume using a snapshot
If an EBS volume is encrypted, its snapshots will be encrypted also
EBS volumes are only stored within one AZ
booleanQuestions.popup: To make sure you don't lose your data, back it up with a snapshot so you can create another volume in another AZ

booleanQuestions.question: EBS volumes can only be attached to EC2 instances within the same AZ
EBS volumes be attached to any EC2 instance within your region
booleanQuestions.popup: They can only attach to EC2 instances within their same AZ in their region

booleanQuestions.question: Every write to an EBS volume is replicated multiple times within the same AZ
There is a region specific setting to always encrypt EBS volumes
If running low, you can give an EBS volume more memory from the AWS console and CLI
EBS is great for data that is constantly changing with a high I/O rate
For Amazon FSx for Windows File Server, you are charged for throughput
For Amazon FSx for Lustre, you are charged for throughput
booleanQuestions.popup: You are charged for throughput using Amazon FSx for Windows File Server

booleanQuestions.question: FSx for Windows File Server is better for compute-intensive workloads (such as machine learning and HPC) than FSx for Lustre
booleanQuestions.popup: Amazon FSx for Lustre is better for compute-intensive workloads

booleanQuestions.question: FSx for Windows File Server and FSx for Lustre both provide sub-millisecond latencies
It's the same price to use FSx for Windows File Server in one AZ as it is multiple AZs
booleanQuestions.popup: It is much more expensive to use multiple AZs

booleanQuestions.question: AWS Storage Gateway's, File Gateaway connects and syncs your on-prem data to S3
AWS Storage Gateway's, Tape Gateway allows you to backup VTL (Virtual Tape Library) to S3, S3 Glacier, and S3 Glacier Deep Archive
AWS Storage Gateway's Volume Gateway option consists of Stored Volume Gateway and Cached Volume Gateway
AWS Storage Gateway's Volume Gateway's, Stored Volume Gateway backs up data to S3 as snapshots, but also keeps data on-prem for lower latencies
AWS Storage Gateway's, Volume Gateway's, Cached Volume Gateway keeps data in S3, but caches recently accessed data for lower latencies
In AWS Backup, through tags, you can create tag-based backup policies, to ensure you capture all of the required resources at once within your plan
AWS Backup provides warm and cold storage options through S3
There is always a charge retrieving datat with AWS Backup
booleanQuestions.popup: It depends on the service being backed up. Sometimes it's free, other times it's based on a GB per month cost

booleanQuestions.question: You can move data from S3 to S3 Glacier using a lifecycle rule
Users can get a Signed URL from CloudFront to temporarily view an S3 Object
You can create an encrypted snapshot from an unencrypted EBS volume
booleanQuestions.popup: Either both are encrypted, or neither are

booleanQuestions.question: You can copy EBS volume snapshots from one region to another
S3 sits inside of your VPC
booleanQuestions.popup: It sits outside of your VPC and is accessed over the public internet

checkboxQuestions.question: What are ways to control access to an S3 bucket?
answers: Option in bucket's settings to block all public access
Using CORS to determine who can make requests (in the bucket policy)

answers: is a fully managed, highly available and durable service
can easily scale to petabytes in size with low latency access
can maintain a high level of throughput (MB/s)
wrongAnswers: is replicated to multiple AZs in multiple regions
can only be used for one EC2 instance

What are the EFS Throughput Modes?
There are 2 types of KMS keys:
answers: Keys imported to AWS from another key management application
Keys created and managed by KMS

checkboxQuestions.question: What are the forms of FSx?
answers: Amazon FSx for Windows File Server

checkboxQuestions.question: What are the 3 options of AWS Storage Gateway
What does a Backup Plan in the AWS Backup service consist of?
answers: Lifecycle rules (such as when to move backups to cold storage)
A backup vault (where backups are encrypted with KMS encryption keys)

checkboxQuestions.question: Amazon Elastic Block Store provides block level storage volumes for use with EC2 instances. EBS volumes are highly available and reliable storage volumes that can be attached to any running instance that is in the same availability zone. Which of the following would be considered a feature of EBS?
answers: EBS volumes behave like raw, unformatted block devices. You can create a file system on top of these volumes, or use them in any other way you would use a block device (like a hard drive)
You can use encrypted EBS volumes to meet a wide range of data-at-rest encryption requirements for regulated/audited data and applications

You can create point-in-time snapshots of EBS volumes, which are persisted to Amazon S3. Snapshots protect data for long-term durability, and they can be used as the starting point for new EBS volumes
wrongAnswers: EBS volumes are created in a specific region, and can then be attached to any instances in that same region
Your account does not have a limit on the number of EBS volumes that you can use, and the total storage available to your is also unlimited
